author: COMSOL
description:
Plasmonic hole arrays can exhibit large transmission also for holes smaller than the wavelength. This has been attributed to the existence of surface plasmon polaritons, which can tunnel electromagnetic energy through the hole even if it is much smaller than the wavelength.

This example is intended as a tutorial that shows how to model the full time-dependent wave equation in a dispersive medium, where the polarization can be expressed as a sum of Drude–Lorentz resonant terms. Each Drude–Lorentz polarization field is solved using an ordinary differential equation, driven by the electric field.

The 2D geometry consists of a single dispersive slab of thickness 1µm with a slit of width 0.5µm in it. The wavelength used is 1µm. Periodic boundary conditions are applied, thus physically this is an array of slits. The incoming wave is a plane wave pulse with flat front and a Gaussian temporal shape.
label: drude_lorentz_media.mph
name: root
